contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox astronaut | name =Pedro Duque Duque | image =Pedro Duque-detail.jpg | type =[[ESA]] Astronaut | nationality =[[Spain|Spanish]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1963|3|14|df=yes}} | birth_place =[[Madrid]], [[Spain]] | occupation =[[Flight engineer]] | selection =[[List of astronauts by selection#1992|1992 ESA Group]] | time =18d 18h 46m |awards = [[Crosses of Aeronautical Merit (Spain)|Grand Cross of Aeronautical Merit]]<br>[[Prince of Asturias Awards#International Cooperation (Cooperación Internacional)|Prince of Asturias Award for International Cooperation]]<br>[[Order of Friendship]]<br>[[Medal "For Merit in Space Exploration"]] | mission =[[STS-95]], [[Soyuz TMA-3]]/[[Soyuz TMA-2|TMA-2]] | insignia =[[Image:Sts-95-patch.png|30px]] [http://esamultimedia.esa.int/images/Duque/Cervantes_mission_logo.jpg Cervantes Logo] |}} {{Spanish name|Duque|Duque}} '''Pedro Duque Duque''' (born 14 March 1963) is a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[astronaut]] and a veteran of two space missions. Duque earned a degree in Aeronautical Engineering from the [[Universidad Politécnica de Madrid]] (UPM) in 1986. He worked for [[GMV, S.A.|GMV]] and for the [[European Space Agency]] (ESA) for six years before being selected as an astronaut candidate in 1992. Duque underwent training in both [[Russia]] and the [[United States]]. His first spaceflight was as a mission specialist aboard [[space shuttle]] mission [[STS-95]], during which Duque supervised ESA experimental modules. In October 2003, Duque visited the [[International Space Station]] for several days during a crew changeover. The scientific program of this visit was called by ESA/Spain [http://www.esa.int/SPECIALS/Cervantes_mission/index.html Misión Cervantes]. He worked at the UPM, in the {{lang|es|Escuela Técnica Superior de Ingenieros Aeronáuticos}},<ref> {{cite web | title = El Astronauta e Ingeniero Aeronáutico Pedro Duque "ficha" por su Escuela | url = http://www.aero.upm.es/es/pedro_duque/pedro_duque.html | date = 2004-10-21 | accessdate = 2005-04-28 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20041208085022/http://www.aero.upm.es/es/pedro_duque/pedro_duque.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2004-12-08}} {{es icon}}</ref> he used to work at [http://www.deimos-imaging.com Deimos Imaging]. Currently he is back as an [[astronaut]] of ESA, and leads the Flight Operations Office near Munich. == See also == *[[List of astronauts]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.esa.int/esaHS/ESAREUZUMOC_astronauts_0.html ESA Biography] *[http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/duque.html NASA Biography] *[http://www.spacefacts.de/bios/international/english/duque_pedro.htm Spacefacts biography of Pedro Duque] *[http://www.grupobcc.com/conferenciante/pedro_duque Events and Conferences] *[http://sites.google.com/a/astrocamp.es/astrocamp-en/ Telescope Hosting site in Nerpio, Spain] {{NASA Astronaut Group 16}} {{Authority control|VIAF=87421006}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Duque, Pedro | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1963-03-14 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Madrid]], [[Spain]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} [[Category:Spanish astronauts]] [[Category:European astronauts]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:European Space Agency personnel]] [[Category:Polytechnic University of Madrid alumni]] {{Spain-bio-stub}} {{astronaut-stub}} {{ESA-stub}} {{Space program of Spain}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Duque, Pedro}}
